Arendt shared an interest in the mysteries of legal personality at this particular moment with Ernst Kantorowicz, the author of The King’s Two Bodies, a work published in 1957 that developed out of an earlier reflection on the mystical medieval origins of sovereignty from a shorter essay written for a festschrift for Max Radin, a legal philosopher who developed some of the central twentieth-century legal writing on the subject of corporate legal personality. Kantorowicz argued that medieval corporation theory built on Roman legal conceptual foundations but acquired a deeper conception of the immortality of legal constructions like corporations, and later states, from its medieval ideas about the eternal life of angels and the doctrine of corpus Christi, entities that maintain their identity in spite of change.
